name: Theorem 11.1.4 – Medians of a Triangle Are Concurrent

blocks.content: Theorem 11.1.4 – Medians of a Triangle Are Concurrent

blocks.alt: Triangle with all three medians meeting at G

blocks.content: **Book Statement**: “The medians of a triangle are concurrent and their point of concurrency is the point of trisection of each median.”
**Median**: A line segment from a vertex to the midpoint of the opposite side.
**Concurrent**: Lines are concurrent if they all meet at a single point (not to be confused with congruent).
**Trisection**: A segment is divided into three equal parts; here, the centroid divides the median in a 2:1 ratio from vertex to midpoint.
The centroid is the point of concurrency of the three medians and lies 2 parts from the vertex and 1 part from the midpoint.

**What We Will Prove**:
1. All three medians of a triangle meet at one point (concurrency).
2. That point divides each median in a 2:1 ratio.

rows: Build a parallelogram inside the triangle
Parallelogram forces the third median to pass through the same point
Diagonals of a parallelogram bisect one another
Pre-marked equal segments give the 2 : 1 split

blocks.alt: Parallelogram HBCH emphasized to show Step 1 visually

blocks.content:
**Step 1 — Build the Parallelogram**:
We begin with two medians intersecting at point G. By marking AG = GH and using the midpoint theorem, we show that GE ∥ HC and GF ∥ HB. This creates a parallelogram HBCH inside the triangle.

**Step 2 — The Third Median Must Pass Through G**:
Since HBCH is a parallelogram, its diagonals bisect each other. The diagonal through G reaches the midpoint of BC, forming the third median AD. Thus all three medians pass through G — proving concurrency.

**Step 3 — Proving the 2 : 1 Ratio**:
With AG = GH and GD equal to each of those segments (from parallelogram symmetry), we conclude that the full median has three equal parts. AG is twice GD, so the centroid lies 2:1 from vertex to midpoint.
